sn35.146:1.1: “Mendicants, I will teach you old action, new action, the cessation of action, and the practice that leads to the cessation of action.
sn35.146:1.2: Listen and pay close attention, I will speak. …
sn35.146:1.4: The eye is old action. It should be seen as produced by choices and intentions, as something to be felt.
sn35.146:1.6: mind is old action. It should be seen as produced by choices and intentions, as something to be felt.
sn35.146:1.9: The deeds you currently perform by way of body, speech, and mind.
sn35.146:1.11: And what is the cessation of action?
sn35.146:1.12: When you experience freedom due to the cessation of deeds by body, speech, and mind.
sn35.146:1.13: This is called the cessation of action.
sn35.146:1.14: And what’s the practice that leads to the cessation of action?
sn35.146:1.15: It is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:
sn35.146:1.16: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.
sn35.146:1.17: This is called the practice that leads to the cessation of action.
sn35.146:1.18: So, mendicants, I’ve taught you old action, new action, the cessation of action, and the practice that leads to the cessation of action.
sn35.146:1.19: Out of compassion, I’ve done what a teacher should do who wants what’s best for their disciples.
sn35.146:1.20: Here are these roots of trees, and here are these empty huts. Practice absorption, mendicants! Don’t be negligent! Don’t regret it later! This is my instruction to you.”
